# _Nix v. Hedden_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

United States Supreme Court case

Nix v. Hedden  
---  
[![Seal of the United States Supreme
Court.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Seal_of_the_United_States_Supreme_Court.svg/100px-
Seal_of_the_United_States_Supreme_Court.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Seal_of_the_United_States_Supreme_Court.svg)**[Supreme
Court of the United States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme
Court of the United States")**  
Submitted April 24, 1892  
Decided May 10, 1893  
Full case name|  _John Nix, John W. Nix, George W. Nix, and Frank W. Nix v.
Edward L. Hedden, Collector of the Port of New York_  
Citations|  149 [U.S.](/wiki/United_States_Reports "United States Reports")
[304](https://supreme.justia.com/us/149/304/case.html)
(_[more](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_149 "List of
United States Supreme Court cases, volume 149")_)149 U.S. 304; 13 S. Ct. 981;
37 L. Ed. 745; 1893 U.S. LEXIS 2303  
Prior history|  Judgment for defendant, 39 F. 109 (C.C. S.D.N.Y. 1889)  
Subsequent history|  None  
Holding  
Tomatoes are "vegetables" and not "fruit" within the meaning of the Tariff Act
of 1883 based on the common meaning of those words.  
Court membership  
  
Chief Justice

    [Melville Fuller](/wiki/Melville_Fuller "Melville Fuller")
Associate Justices

    [Stephen J. Field](/wiki/Stephen_Johnson_Field "Stephen Johnson Field") **·** [John M. Harlan](/wiki/John_Marshall_Harlan "John Marshall Harlan")  
[Horace Gray](/wiki/Horace_Gray "Horace Gray") **·** [Samuel
Blatchford](/wiki/Samuel_Blatchford "Samuel Blatchford")  
[David J. Brewer](/wiki/David_Josiah_Brewer "David Josiah Brewer") **·**
[Henry B. Brown](/wiki/Henry_Billings_Brown "Henry Billings Brown")  
[George Shiras Jr.](/wiki/George_Shiras_Jr. "George Shiras Jr.") **·** [Howell
E. Jackson](/wiki/Howell_Edmunds_Jackson "Howell Edmunds Jackson")  
Case opinions  
Majority|  Gray, joined by _unanimous_  
Laws applied  
[Tariff Act of 1883](/wiki/Tariff_Act_of_1883 "Tariff Act of 1883") (Mongrel
Tariff)  
  
_**Nix v. Hedden**_ ,
[149](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_149 "List of
United States Supreme Court cases, volume 149")
[U.S.](/wiki/United_States_Reports "United States Reports")
[304](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/149/304/) (1893),[1] was a
decision by the [Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States") that, under U.S. customs regulations, the [tomato](/wiki/Tomato
"Tomato") should be [classified](/wiki/Tomato#Fruit_or_vegetable.3F "Tomato")
as a [vegetable](/wiki/Vegetable "Vegetable") rather than a
[fruit](/wiki/Fruit "Fruit"). The Court's unanimous opinion held that the
[Tariff Act of 1883](/wiki/Tariff_Act_of_1883 "Tariff Act of 1883") used the
ordinary meaning of the words
"[fruit](/wiki/Fruit#Botanic_fruit_and_culinary_fruit "Fruit")" and
"[vegetable](/wiki/Vegetable#Terminology "Vegetable")," instead of the
technical botanical meaning.

## Contents

  * 1 Background of the case
  * 2 The Court's decision
  * 3 Subsequent jurisprudence
  * 4 See also
  * 5 Notes
  * 6 References
  * 7 External links

## Background of the
case[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nix_v._Hedden&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Background of the case")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|
This section **needs additional citations
for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**.
Please help [improve this
article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nix_v._Hedden&action=edit) by
[adding citations to reliable
sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1
"Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may
be challenged and removed. _(May 2014)__([Learn how and when to remove this
template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance
template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
John Nix founded the John Nix & Co. fruit commission in New York City in 1839.
The company became one of the largest sellers of produce in New York City at
the time, and was one of the first companies to ship produce from
[Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"), [Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida"), and
[Bermuda](/wiki/Bermuda "Bermuda") to New York.[2]

In 1883, President [Chester A. Arthur](/wiki/Chester_A._Arthur "Chester A.
Arthur") signed the [Tariff Act of March 3, 1883](/wiki/Tariff_of_1883 "Tariff
of 1883"), requiring a tax to be paid on imported vegetables, but not fruit.
The John Nix & Co. company filed a suit against Edward L. Hedden, [Collector
of the Port of New York](/wiki/Collector_of_the_Port_of_New_York "Collector of
the Port of New York"), to recover back duties paid under protest. They argued
against the tariff by pointing out that, [botanically](/wiki/Botany "Botany"),
a tomato is a fruit due to its seed-bearing structure growing from the
flowering part of a plant.[3]

At the trial, the [plaintiffs](/wiki/Plaintiff "Plaintiff")' counsel entered
into [evidence](/wiki/Evidence_\(law\) "Evidence \(law\)") definitions of the
words "fruit" and "vegetables" from [Webster's
Dictionary](/wiki/Webster%27s_Dictionary "Webster's Dictionary"), Worcester's
Dictionary, and the [Imperial
Dictionary](/wiki/Imperial_Dictionary_of_the_English_Language "Imperial
Dictionary of the English Language"). They called two
[witnesses](/wiki/Witness "Witness"), who had been in the business of selling
fruit and vegetables for 30 years, and asked them, after hearing these
definitions, to say whether these words had "any special meaning in
[trade](/wiki/Trade "Trade") or [commerce](/wiki/Commerce "Commerce"),
different from those read."

During testimony, one witness testified that in regard to the dictionary
definition:

> [the dictionary] does not classify all things there, but they are correct as
> far as they go. It does not take all kinds of fruit or vegetables; it takes
> a portion of them. I think the words 'fruit' and 'vegetable' have the same
> meaning in trade today that they had on March 1, 1883. I understand that the
> term 'fruit' is applied in trade only to such plants or parts of plants as
> contain the seeds. There are more vegetables than those in the enumeration
> given in Webster's Dictionary under the term 'vegetable,' as 'cabbage,
> cauliflower, turnips, potatoes, peas, beans, and the like,' probably covered
> by the words 'and the like'

Another witness testified that "I don't think the term 'fruit' or the term
'vegetables' had, in March 1883, and prior thereto, any special meaning in
trade and commerce in this country different from that which I have read here
from the dictionaries."[4]

Both the plaintiffs' counsel and the defendant's counsel made use of the
dictionaries. The plaintiffs' counsel read in evidence from the same
dictionaries the definitions of the word tomato, while the defendant's counsel
then read in evidence from Webster's Dictionary the definitions of the words
[pea](/wiki/Pea "Pea"), [eggplant](/wiki/Eggplant "Eggplant"),
[cucumber](/wiki/Cucumber "Cucumber"), [squash](/wiki/Squash_\(plant\) "Squash
\(plant\)"), and [pepper](/wiki/Capsicum "Capsicum").[5] Countering this, the
plaintiff then read in evidence from Webster's and Worcester's dictionaries
the definitions of [potato](/wiki/Potato "Potato"), [turnip](/wiki/Turnip
"Turnip"), [parsnip](/wiki/Parsnip "Parsnip"), [cauliflower](/wiki/Cauliflower
"Cauliflower"), [cabbage](/wiki/Cabbage "Cabbage"), [carrot](/wiki/Carrot
"Carrot") and [bean](/wiki/Bean "Bean").

## The Court's
decision[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nix_v._Hedden&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: The Court's decision")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Bright_red_tomato_and_cross_section02.jpg/220px-
Bright_red_tomato_and_cross_section02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bright_red_tomato_and_cross_section02.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bright_red_tomato_and_cross_section02.jpg "Enlarge")

Botanically, a tomato is a fruit. However, in common parlance it is seen as a
vegetable; hence the United States Supreme Court ruled that a tomato is a
vegetable for the purposes of the customs regulations.

The court [unanimously](/wiki/Unanimous "Unanimous") decided in favor of the
respondent and found that the tomato should be classified under the customs
regulations as a vegetable, based on the ways in which it is used, and the
popular perception to this end. Justice [Horace Gray](/wiki/Horace_Gray
"Horace Gray"), writing the opinion for the Court, stated that:

> The passages cited from the dictionaries define the word 'fruit' as the seed
> of plants, or that part of plants which contains the seed, and especially
> the juicy, pulpy products of certain plants, covering and containing the
> seed. These definitions have no tendency to show that tomatoes are 'fruit,'
> as distinguished from 'vegetables,' in common speech, or within the meaning
> of the [tariff](/wiki/Tariff "Tariff") act.

Justice Gray, citing several Supreme Court cases (_[Brown v.
Piper](/w/index.php?title=Brown_v._Piper&action=edit&redlink=1 "Brown v. Piper
\(page does not exist\)"),_ [91 U.S.
37](http://www.justia.us/us/91/37/case.html),
[42](http://www.justia.us/us/91/42/case.html)[_[permanent dead
link](/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot "Wikipedia:Link rot")_], and _[Jones v.
U.S.](/w/index.php?title=Jones_v._U.S.&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jones v. U.S.
\(page does not exist\)"),_ 137 U.S. 202, 216) stated that when words have
acquired no special meaning in trade or commerce, the ordinary meaning must be
used by the court. In this case dictionaries cannot be admitted as evidence,
but only as aids to the memory and understanding of the court. Gray
acknowledged that [botanically](/wiki/Botany "Botany"), tomatoes are
classified as a "fruit of the [vine](/wiki/Vine "Vine")"; nevertheless, they
are seen as vegetables because they were usually eaten as a main course
instead of being eaten as a [dessert](/wiki/Dessert "Dessert"). In making his
decision, Justice Gray mentioned another case where it had been claimed that
[beans](/wiki/Bean "Bean") were [seeds](/wiki/Seed "Seed") — Justice
[Bradley](/wiki/Joseph_Philo_Bradley "Joseph Philo Bradley"), in _[Robertson
v. Salomon](/w/index.php?title=Robertson_v._Salomon&action=edit&redlink=1
"Robertson v. Salomon \(page does not exist\)"),_ 130 U.S. 412, 414, similarly
found that though a bean is botanically a seed, in [common
parlance](/wiki/Idiom "Idiom") a bean is seen as a vegetable. While on the
subject, Gray clarified the status of the [cucumber](/wiki/Cucumber
"Cucumber"), [squash](/wiki/Squash_\(plant\) "Squash \(plant\)"),
[pea](/wiki/Pea "Pea"), and [bean](/wiki/Bean "Bean").

## Subsequent
jurisprudence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nix_v._Hedden&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Subsequent jurisprudence")]

_Nix_ has been cited in three Supreme Court decisions as a precedent for court
interpretation of common meanings, especially dictionary definitions. (_[Sonn
v. Maggone](/w/index.php?title=Sonn_v._Maggone&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sonn v.
Maggone \(page does not exist\)"),_
[159](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_159 "List of
United States Supreme Court cases, volume 159")
[U.S.](/wiki/United_States_Reports "United States Reports")
[417](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/159/417/) (1895);
_[Saltonstall v. Wiebusch&
Hilger](/w/index.php?title=Saltonstall_v._Wiebusch_%26_Hilger&action=edit&redlink=1
"Saltonstall v. Wiebusch & Hilger \(page does not exist\)"),_
[156](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_156 "List of
United States Supreme Court cases, volume 156")
[U.S.](/wiki/United_States_Reports "United States Reports")
[601](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/156/601/) (1895); and
_[Cadwalader v.
Zeh](/w/index.php?title=Cadwalader_v._Zeh&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cadwalader v.
Zeh \(page does not exist\)"),_
[151](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_151 "List of
United States Supreme Court cases, volume 151")
[U.S.](/wiki/United_States_Reports "United States Reports")
[171](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/151/171/) (1894)).
Additionally, in _[JSG Trading Corp. v. Tray-Wrap,
Inc.](/w/index.php?title=JSG_Trading_Corp._v._Tray-
Wrap,_Inc.&action=edit&redlink=1 "JSG Trading Corp. v. Tray-Wrap, Inc. \(page
does not exist\)"),_ 917 F.2d 75 (2d Cir. 1990), a case unrelated to _Nix_
aside from the shared focus on tomatoes, a judge wrote the following paragraph
citing the case:

> In common parlance tomatoes are vegetables, as the Supreme Court observed
> long ago [see _Nix v. Hedden_ 149 U.S. 304, 307, 13 S.Ct. 881, 882, 37 L.Ed.
> 745 (1893)], although botanically speaking they are actually a fruit. [_26
> Encyclopedia Americana_ 832 (Int'l. ed. 1981)]. Regardless of
> classification, people have been enjoying tomatoes for centuries; even [Mr.
> Pickwick](/wiki/Samuel_Pickwick "Samuel Pickwick"), as
> [Dickens](/wiki/Charles_Dickens "Charles Dickens") relates, ate his chops in
> "tomata" sauce.

In 2005, supporters in the New Jersey legislature cited _Nix_ as a basis for a
bill designating the tomato as the official [state
vegetable](/wiki/United_States_state_symbols "United States state
symbols").[6]

## See also[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Nix_v._Hedden&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: See also")]

  * [Carrot](/wiki/Carrot "Carrot") – defined to be a fruit in [European Union law](/wiki/European_Union_law "European Union law"), for the purpose of [jam](/wiki/Jam "Jam") classification; Annex III(A)(1), Council Directive 2001/113/EC of 20 December 2001 relating to fruit jams, jellies and marmalades and sweetened chestnut purée intended for human consumption
  * [Ketchup as a vegetable](/wiki/Ketchup_as_a_vegetable "Ketchup as a vegetable")
  * [Jaffa Cakes](/wiki/Jaffa_Cakes#Categorisation_as_cake_or_biscuit_for_VAT "Jaffa Cakes"), the subject of a 1991 UK tribunal which decided that they were cakes, rather than biscuits (cookies), which would attract [value-added tax](/wiki/Value-added_tax_\(United_Kingdom\) "Value-added tax \(United Kingdom\)").
  * _[Toy Biz v. United States](/wiki/Toy_Biz_v._United_States "Toy Biz v. United States")_ – decided that action figures of certain [superheroes](/wiki/Superhero "Superhero") are legally [toys](/wiki/Toy "Toy"), not [dolls](/wiki/Doll "Doll")
  * [List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 149](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_149 "List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 149")

nq_863_9.Query Analysis: The query seeks to determine whether the US Supreme Court has classified a tomato as a fruit or a vegetable.
nq_863_9.Query Keywords Extraction: tomato, fruit, vegetable, US Supreme Court
nq_863_9.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that the tomato is classified as a vegetable.
nq_863_9.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the classification of tomatoes, referencing Supreme Court cases and Justice Gray's opinion. It mentions that tomatoes are botanically classified as a fruit but are considered vegetables in common speech and within the context of the tariff act. The document also touches on the general principle of using ordinary meanings in court unless a special meaning in trade or commerce has been established.
nq_863_9.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document explicitly states that tomatoes are seen as vegetables, matching the answer.
nq_863_9.Key Information Matching: The document directly addresses the classification of tomatoes as vegetables, which is the core of the query, and references Supreme Court decisions relevant to this classification.

nq_863_9.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides context on how the Supreme Court interprets such classifications and the rationale behind considering tomatoes as vegetables.
nq_863_9.Explanation: The document is directly relevant to the query as it provides a clear answer and additional context on the Supreme Court's reasoning for classifying tomatoes as vegetables. It directly addresses the main topic of the query and enhances understanding of the legal perspective on the classification.
